para.p:
We take
N
to be the set of positive integers. If
A
is a set and
∈ n N
, we typically deal with the product
A n
as the set of functions
→
{ 1 , … , n }
A
.
In this note I am following and greatly expanding the proof of the Bochner-Minlos theorem given by Barry Simon, Functional Integration and Quantum Physics, p. 11, Theorem 2.2.

If
X
is a topological space, and for
≥ m n
the maps
:
π
m , n
→
X m
X n
are defined by

Math.text: formulae@(pi _ (list@(m, n)) * x * j = x * j, j element-of set@(1, ldots, n))

para.p:
then the spaces
X n
and maps
π
m , n
constitute a projective system, and its limit in the category of topological spaces is
X N
with the maps
:
π n
→
X N
X n
, where
X N
has the initial topology for the family
{
π n
:
∈ n N
}
(namely, the product topology). We say that a function
: f
→
X N
R
depends on only finitely many coordinates if there is some
n
and some function
: g
→
X n
R
such that
= f
∘ g
π n
. We denote by
⁢
C fin
(
X N
)
the set of all continuous functions
→
X N
R
that depend on only finitely many coordinates.

If
( X ,
τ X
)

{ ∞ }

(

, τ )

→ X

( X )

∈ f

( X )

(

)

f

∈ g
⁢
C 0
( X )

+ g c

Math.text: F * x = cases@(f * x, x element-of X, c, x = infinity)

para.p:
We call
˙ X
the one-point compactification of
X
. For example, one checks that the one-point compactification of
R n
is homeomorphic to
S n
.

n

A
in

μ n

para.p:

*

x , y
R N

Math.text: ((norm@(iota _ (list@(m, n)) * x)) _ n) ^ 2 = ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ infinity)@(j ^ (2 * n) * iota _ (list@(m, n)) * x * j ^ 2) = ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ infinity)@(j ^ (2 * m) * j ^ (2 * (n - m)) * x * j ^ 2) less= ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ infinity)@(j ^ (2 * m) * x * j ^ 2)

((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ infinity)@(j ^ (2 * m) * x * j ^ 2)

the map
ι
m , n
is a bounded operator. In fact, if
> m n

m , n
is a Hilbert-Schmidt operator, and so compact, which is the conclusion of Rellich’s theorem. For
∈ i N

∈
e i
R N

Math.text: e _ i * j = j ^ (- m) * delta _ (list@(i, j))

para.p:
These
e i
are an orthonormal basis for
S m
, and

Math.text: ((sum _ (i = 1)) ^ infinity)@(((norm@(iota _ (list@(m, n)) * e _ i)) _ n) ^ 2) = ((sum _ (i = 1)) ^ infinity)@(((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ infinity)@(j ^ (2 * n) * iota _ (list@(m, n)) * e _ i * j ^ 2)) = ((sum _ (i = 1)) ^ infinity)@(((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ infinity)@(j ^ (2 * n) * (j ^ (- m) * delta _ (list@(i, j))) ^ 2)) = ((sum _ (i = 1)) ^ infinity)@(i ^ (2 * n) * i ^ (- 2 * m)) = ((sum _ (i = 1)) ^ infinity)@(i ^ (2 * (n - m)))
((sum _ (i = 1)) ^ infinity)@(((norm@(iota _ (list@(m, n)) * e _ i)) _ n) ^ 2)
((sum _ (i = 1)) ^ infinity)@(((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ infinity)@(j ^ (2 * n) * iota _ (list@(m, n)) * e _ i * j ^ 2))
((sum _ (i = 1)) ^ infinity)@(((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ infinity)@(j ^ (2 * n) * (j ^ (- m) * delta _ (list@(i, j))) ^ 2))
((sum _ (i = 1)) ^ infinity)@(i ^ (2 * (n - m)))

Because
> m n

<
∞
. This shows that

(norm@(x)) _ m * (norm@(lambda)) _ (- m)

para.p:
S
- m

with the weak-* topology with which it is a locally convex space, rather than with the norm topology with which it is a Banach space.

so

S *
is a topological space and so has a Borel
σ
-algebra. We shall now define a
σ
-algebra on
S *

σ

S *
and denoted
⁢ Cyl
(
S *
)

σ

S *

∈ x S

L x
→
S *
R
by
⁢
L x
( λ )
=

( x )
=

. We define
⁢ Cyl
(
S *
)
to be the coarsest
σ
-algebra such that for each
∈ x S
, the map
:
L x
→
S *
R
is measurable, where
R
has the Borel
σ
-algebra. Since each
L x
is continuous,
L x
is measurable with respect to the Borel
σ
-algebra on
S *
, so
⁢ Cyl
(
S *
)
is contained in the Borel
σ
-algebra of
S *
; it is not obvious that the cylinder
σ
-algebra is strictly contained in the Borel
σ
-algebra. Unless we say otherwise, when we speak of measurable functions on
S *
or measures on
S *
we mean with respect to the cylinder
σ
-algebra.

μ
on

B

=
B 0

S

B 0

( S )
, and that
⁢ Cyl
( S )
does not contain the Borel
σ
-algbera of
S
, and thus that the restriction of
μ
to
S
is not a Borel measure.

Math.tex: \displaystyle\int_{\mathbb{R}^{N}}y_{i}y_{j}d\sigma_{\alpha,N}(y)=\delta_{i,j}% \int_{\mathbb{R}}\cdots\int_{\mathbb{R}}y_{j}^{2}\prod_{k=1}^{N}(2\pi\alpha q_% {k})^{-1/2}\exp\left(-\frac{y_{k}^{2}}{2\alpha q_{k}}\right)dy_{k}=\delta_{i,j% }\left(\prod_{k\neq j}\int_{\mathbb{R}}(2\pi\alpha q_{k})^{-1/2}\exp\left(-% \frac{y_{k}^{2}}{2\alpha q_{k}}\right)dy_{k}\right)\cdot\int_{\mathbb{R}}y_{j}% ^{2}(2\pi\alpha q_{j})^{-1/2}\exp\left(-\frac{y_{j}^{2}}{2\alpha q_{j}}\right)% dy_{j}=\delta_{i,j}\int_{\mathbb{R}}y_{j}^{2}(2\pi\alpha q_{j})^{-1/2}\exp% \left(-\frac{y_{j}^{2}}{2\alpha q_{j}}\right)dy_{j}=\delta_{i,j}\alpha q_{j}.
Math.text: (integral _ (R ^ N))@(y _ i * y _ j * differential-d@(sigma _ (list@(alpha, N))) * y) = delta _ (list@(i, j)) * (integral _ R)@(cdots * (integral _ R)@((y _ j) ^ 2 * ((product _ (k = 1)) ^ N)@((2 * pi * alpha * q _ k) ^ (- 1 / 2) * exponential@(- (y _ k) ^ 2 / (2 * alpha * q _ k)) * d * y _ k))) = (delta _ (list@(i, j)) * (product _ (k not-equals j))@((integral _ R)@((2 * pi * alpha * q _ k) ^ (- 1 / 2) * exponential@(- (y _ k) ^ 2 / (2 * alpha * q _ k)) * differential-d@(y _ k)))) cdot (integral _ R)@((y _ j) ^ 2 * (2 * pi * alpha * q _ j) ^ (- 1 / 2) * exponential@(- (y _ j) ^ 2 / (2 * alpha * q _ j)) * differential-d@(y _ j)) = delta _ (list@(i, j)) * (integral _ R)@((y _ j) ^ 2 * (2 * pi * alpha * q _ j) ^ (- 1 / 2) * exponential@(- (y _ j) ^ 2 / (2 * alpha * q _ j)) * differential-d@(y _ j)) = delta _ (list@(i, j)) * alpha * q _ j
(integral _ (R ^ N))@(y _ i * y _ j * differential-d@(sigma _ (list@(alpha, N))) * y)

delta _ (list@(i, j)) * (integral _ R)@(cdots * (integral _ R)@((y _ j) ^ 2 * ((product _ (k = 1)) ^ N)@((2 * pi * alpha * q _ k) ^ (- 1 / 2) * exponential@(- (y _ k) ^ 2 / (2 * alpha * q _ k)) * d * y _ k)))

delta _ (list@(i, j)) * alpha * q _ j

Math.text: (integral _ (R ^ N))@(e ^ (- (i * x) cdot y) * differential-d@(sigma _ (list@(alpha, N))) * y) = ((product _ (k = 1)) ^ N)@((integral _ R)@(e ^ (- i * x _ k * y _ k) * (2 * pi * alpha * q _ k) ^ (- 1 / 2) * exponential@(- (y _ k) ^ 2 / (2 * alpha * q _ k)) * differential-d@(y _ k))) = ((product _ (k = 1)) ^ N)@(exponential@(- (alpha * q _ k * (x _ k) ^ 2) / 2)) = exponential@(- (alpha / 2) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ N)@(q _ k * (x _ k) ^ 2))

exponential@(- (alpha / 2) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ N)@(q _ k * (x _ k) ^ 2))

Math.text: Re * (integral _ (R ^ N))@(Phi * (pi _ N) ^ * * y * differential-d@(sigma _ (list@(alpha, N))) * y) = Re * (integral _ (R ^ N))@((integral _ (R ^ N))@(exponential@(- i * list@((pi _ N) ^ * * y, x)) * differential-d@(mu) * x * differential-d@(sigma _ (list@(alpha, N))) * y)) = Re * (integral _ (R ^ N))@((integral _ (R ^ N))@(exponential@(- ((i * y) cdot pi _ N) * x) * differential-d@(sigma _ (list@(alpha, N))) * y * differential-d@(mu) * x)) = Re * (integral _ (R ^ N))@(exponential@(- (alpha / 2) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ N)@(q _ k * (x _ k) ^ 2)) * differential-d@(mu) * x) = (integral _ (R ^ N))@(exponential@(- (alpha / 2) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ N)@(q _ k * (x _ k) ^ 2)) * differential-d@(mu) * x)

para.p:
The integral of the right-hand side of () over
R N
with respect to
σ
α , N
is

Math.text: (integral _ (R ^ N))@((1 - epsilon - 2 * delta ^ (- 2) * ((norm@((pi _ N) ^ * * y)) _ m) ^ 2) * differential-d@(sigma _ (list@(alpha, N))) * y) = 1 - epsilon - 2 * delta ^ (- 2) * (integral _ (R ^ N))@(((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ N)@(k ^ (2 * m) * (y _ k) ^ 2 * d * sigma _ (list@(alpha, N)) * y)) = 1 - epsilon - 2 * delta ^ (- 2) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ N)@(k ^ (2 * m) * alpha * (q _ k) ^ 2) = 1 - epsilon - 2 * delta ^ (- 2) * alpha * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ N)@(k ^ (- 2))
(integral _ (R ^ N))@((1 - epsilon - 2 * delta ^ (- 2) * ((norm@((pi _ N) ^ * * y)) _ m) ^ 2) * differential-d@(sigma _ (list@(alpha, N))) * y)
1 - epsilon - 2 * delta ^ (- 2) * (integral _ (R ^ N))@(((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ N)@(k ^ (2 * m) * (y _ k) ^ 2 * d * sigma _ (list@(alpha, N)) * y))
1 - epsilon - 2 * delta ^ (- 2) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ N)@(k ^ (2 * m) * alpha * (q _ k) ^ 2)
1 - epsilon - 2 * delta ^ (- 2) * alpha * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ N)@(k ^ (- 2))

para.p: Combining these, () is

Math.text: (integral _ (R ^ N))@(exponential@(- (alpha / 2) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ N)@(q _ k * (x _ k) ^ 2)) * differential-d@(mu) * x) >= 1 - epsilon - 2 * delta ^ (- 2) * alpha * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ N)@(k ^ (- 2))

para.p:
Taking
→ N ∞
,

Math.text: (integral _ (R ^ N))@(exponential@(- (alpha / 2) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ infinity)@(q _ k * (x _ k) ^ 2)) * differential-d@(mu) * x) >= 1 - epsilon - ((2 * delta ^ (- 2) * alpha) cdot zeta) * 2

para.p: But

Math.text: (limit _ (alpha to 0 ^ +))@(exponential@(- (alpha / 2) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ N)@(q _ k * (x _ k) ^ 2))) = (limit _ (alpha to 0 ^ +))@(exponential@(- (alpha / 2) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ N)@(k ^ (2 * (- m - 1)) * (x _ k) ^ 2))) = cases@(1, x element-of S _ (- m - 1), 0, x not-element-of S _ (- m - 1))
(limit _ (alpha to 0 ^ +))@(exponential@(- (alpha / 2) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ N)@(q _ k * (x _ k) ^ 2)))
(limit _ (alpha to 0 ^ +))@(exponential@(- (alpha / 2) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ N)@(k ^ (2 * (- m - 1)) * (x _ k) ^ 2)))
cases@(1, x element-of S _ (- m - 1), 0, x not-element-of S _ (- m - 1))

para.p:
so taking
→ α
0 +
, () yields

Math.text: (integral _ (R ^ N))@(chi _ S _ (- m - 1) * x * differential-d@(mu) * x) >= 1 - epsilon

para.p:
i.e.
≥
⁢ μ
(

-
- m
1

- 1 ϵ

⁢ μ

. That is, we have proved that for any
> ϵ 0
there is some
∈ m Z

Math.text: mu * S ^ * >= mu * S _ (- m - 1) >= 1 - epsilon

para.p:
which shows that
=
⁢ μ
(
S *

1
, i.e. that
μ
is a probability measure. ∎

There don’t seem to be many detailed presentations of the Bochner-Minlos theorem, or Minlos’s theorem, in the literature. Cf. Sazonov’s theorem. Doing some searching through books, the following look like they have enough details so that they are not worse than nothing, which is more than can always be said:
Helge Holden, Bernt Øksendal, Jan Ubøe and Tusheng Zhang, Stochastic Partial Differential Equations: A Modeling, White Noise Functional Approach, second ed., Appendix A, pp. 257ff.
Takeyuki Hida, Brownian Motion, pp. 116ff., §3.2
I. M. Gelfand and N. Ya. Vilenkin, Generalized Functions. Volume 4: Applications of Harmonic Analysis
V. I. Bogachev, Measure Theory, vol. II, p. 124, Theorem 7.13.7
A. V. Skorokhod, Basic Principles and Applications of Probability Theory, p. 51, §2.4.4
N. Bourbaki, Integration II: Chapters 7–9, p. IX.100, §6, Theorem 4
